Award.AwardTitle: New Plasma Tools for Physics with Low-energy Antimatter
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is made in response to a proposal submitted to and reviewed under the NSF-DoE Partnership in Plasma Science and Engineering joint solicitation, NSF 09-596. The award provides funds to support undergraduate participation in the overall research effort, which is being funded separately by the DoE Award No. DE-FG02-10ER55080.1

Cold antimatter is important in a range of applications. This project will develop new physics tools for antimatter research. Cyclotron cooling of positrons has proven to be an effective and useful tool. The limits of this technique and methods to improve cooling rates will be explored. The rotating wall technique, whereby rotating electric fields are used to compress plasmas radially inward across the magnetic field, has proven to be an exceedingly useful way to achieve high plasma densities and long confinement times. Research will be conducted to find improved ways to compress plasmas and to form cold high-density states. Additionally, a method will be developed to form specially tailored (e.g., cold, bright) positron beams from trapped plasmas, including beams extracted from the magnetic field of the Penning-Malmberg trap.

The undergraduate participation, enabled by this award, adds a broader educational impact through the early-year training of students by introducing them to scientific research as a possible career path.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The fundamental laws of physics, to the extent that we currently understand them, predict that for every particle of matter created in our universe, there will be a corresponding antiparticle. Examples of matter particles and their (antimatter) twins are the proton (antiproton) and electron (positron). One facet of our universe not currently understood is that antiparticles are far less numerous than particles of matter. Nevertheless, antimatter is important in many scientific and technological contexts. One common example is positron emission tomography (PET) to study metabolic processes in humans and other organisms and for use in drug design. The overall objective of the research done in this project was to create novel states of antimatter in our world of matter and develop new tools to manipulate and tailor them for specific scientific and technical uses.

The work had several more specific objectives. One is establishing the limits for positron accumulation and confinement in the form of single-component plasmas in a particular type of electromagnetic trap. This technique underpins a wealth of antimatter applications, including novel positron beams for materials analysis and tests of the fundamental laws of physics, such as the symmetry of antimatter and matter mentioned above. A second objective is to develop an understanding of the limits for formation of cold, bright positron beams. The research in this project focused on particular facets of these goals. One focus was the development of a new type of high-quality beam that could be guided by electric fields (i.e., voltage differences). A second goal was to develop the design for beams with a very narrow energy spread using a cryogenically cooled gas. A third objective was to conduct the basic plasma research necessary to develop a new high-capacity electromagnetic trap for research with, and technological applications of, positrons (i.e., antielectrons). Such a trap might someday be a good way to create a portable trap for antimatter, so that researchers and industrial personnel could have more convenient access to sources of antiparticles for science and technological applications. Some of the techniques developed in the course of this work are also relevant to the manipulation and use of antiprotons.

Progress was made on all three goals. A novel technique was developed to tailor a positron beam in an electromagnetic trap in a large magnetic field and then extract it from the field and focus it using electric fields. Using a combination of computer simulations and experiment, plans were vetted to create an energy-tunable positron beam with an energy spread that is expected to be a factor of five or more smaller than current capabilities. Finally, techniques were developed and tested that are expected to be critical to the construction of a novel array of electromagnetic traps to accumulate and store for days or more two orders of magnitude (i.e., ≥ a factor of one hundred) more positrons than is currently possible, namely the development of a multi-trap array capable of storing one trillion positrons.
